{{other people||Luke Johnson (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Use British English|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Luke Johnson | image = Luke Johnson WES 2014.jpg | caption = Luke Johnson speaking at [[Warwick Economics Summit]] 2014 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1962|2|2|df=yes}} | birth_place = | nationality = British | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Entrepreneur | salary = | networth = £220 million''' (2015) | other_names = Cool Hand Luke<ref name="richlist2008">{{cite news |url= http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/specials/rich_list/article3791261.ece |date=27 April 2008|title=Sunday Times Rich List: Luke Johnson |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612082131/http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/specials/rich_list/article3791261.ece |archive-date=12 June 2011 |newspaper=The Sunday Times |accessdate=13 November 2008 | location=London}}</ref> | known_for = | spouse = | alma_mater = [[Magdalen College, Oxford]] | website = http://www.lukejohnson.org/ | footnotes = | children = 3 | parents = [[Paul Johnson (writer)|Paul Johnson]] and Marigold Hunt | relatives = [[Daniel Johnson (journalist)|Daniel Johnson]] (brother) }} '''Luke Oliver Johnson''' (born 2 February 1962), is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[entrepreneur]], best known for his involvement with [[Pizza Express]] chain. He is a former chairman of the [[Royal Society of Arts]] and [[Channel 4]]. He writes a weekly column for ''[[The Sunday Times]]''. Johnson calls himself a "projector", in line with the 17th century term for a man involved in many different businesses.<ref>{{citenews|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/3021321.stm|title=Pizza Express entrepreneur looks to the future|last=Cummings|first=Laura|date=15 May 2003|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=13 November 2008}}</ref> However, others regard him as just a serial entrepreneur. He is the part owner and chairman of [[Patisserie Valerie]], Gail's Artisan Bakery and [[Feng Sushi]] among other businesses. He is a former owner of [[The Ivy]], Le Caprice and J Sheekey restaurants and a former part owner of [[Giraffe Restaurants]].
==Early years== The son of historian [[Paul Johnson (writer)|Paul Johnson]] and brother of [[Daniel Johnson (journalist)|Daniel Johnson]], he spent his early years in [[Iver]], [[Buckinghamshire]], and was educated at the state run [[Langley Grammar School]] in [[Langley, Berkshire|Langley]], [[Berkshire]], and at [[Magdalen College, Oxford]].
Whilst at university Johnson together with fellow student [[Hugh Osmond]] (later founder of [[Punch Taverns]]) interviewed [[Richard Branson]] on his houseboat in [[London]] for the student newspaper. This gave the pair the inspiration to go into business and they began running the ''Era'' nightclub in [[Oxford]]. By the time of graduation, he and Osmond were running businesses from software to clubs.
He initially studied medicine but, like Hugh Osmond, only completed the first part of the course, graduating from Oxford University with a BA in Physiological Sciences in 1983. He began his career as a media analyst at [[stockbroker]] Grieveson Grant (subsequently [[Kleinwort Benson]] Securities).
==Business career==
===Restaurants and leisure=== [[File:Pattisserie Valerie Sutton Surrey London.JPG|thumb|A [[Patisserie Valerie]] store in [[Sutton High Street]], [[Sutton, London|Sutton]], Greater London]] In 1993, Johnson and Osmond took control of [[Pizza Express]], with Johnson becoming chairman. They expanded the business from 12 owned restaurants to over 250, and the share price from 40p to over 900p.<ref name="aboutluke">{{cite web|url=http://www.lukejohnson.org/about|title=About Luke Johnson}}</ref> After selling the business in 1999 Johnson started Signature Restaurants, a ‘crown jewels’ collection of London restaurants which included [[The Ivy]] and Le Caprice, as well as the [[Belgo]] chain. He also started [[Strada]] restaurants from scratch, taking the chain to 30 units. He sold both businesses in 2005; the total proceeds from these two disposals were in excess of £90 million.<ref name="aboutluke" />
Whilst chairman of the Belgo group, Johnson took part in the [[BBC]] programme "''Back to the Floor''", a programme in which top executives spent a week at the "coal face" of their business. Some reviewers of the programme were uncomplimentary about Johnson.
From 1993 to date, Johnson has been involved as director and/or owner of various companies in retailing, pubs and bars, including [[Whittard of Chelsea]], My Kinda Town and the private companies Giraffe,<ref>Shrimpton, David (25 March 2004). [http://www.caterersearch.com/Articles/0001/01/01/52621/Ex-PizzaExpress-duo-invest-in-Giraffe.htm "Ex-PizzaExpress duo invest in Giraffe"]. ''CatererSearch.com'', Retrieved July 2010.</ref> Druckers<ref>[http://www.growingbusiness.co.uk/former-pizza-express-man-buys-druckers.html?page=3 "Former Pizza Express man buys Druckers"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929144616/http://www.growingbusiness.co.uk/former-pizza-express-man-buys-druckers.html?page=3 |date=29 September 2011 }}, ''Growing Business'', 31 May 2007. Retrieved July 2010.</ref> and Baker & Spice.<ref>Druce, Chris (25 February 2009).[http://www.caterersearch.com/Articles/2009/02/25/326322/luke-johnson-acquires-another-patisserie-chain.htm "Luke Johnson acquires another patisserie chain"]. "Caterer Search". Retrieved 28 July 2011.</ref>. The latter two businesses became part of Patisserie Holdings (see below). In December 2009, Johnson's investment partnership [[Risk Capital Partners]] Ltd acquired the Tootsie's restaurant chain,<ref>[http://dev.growingbusiness.co.uk/johnson-eyes-giraffe-expansion-with-tootsies-deal.html "Johnson eyes Giraffe expansion with Tootsies deal"]. ''Growing Business'', 13 October 2009. Retrieved 28 July 2011. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328071516/http://dev.growingbusiness.co.uk/johnson-eyes-giraffe-expansion-with-tootsies-deal.html |date=28 March 2012 }}</ref> for which it was awarded the "Deal of the Year" prize at the 2010 Retailer's Retailer Awards ceremony. Johnson also purchased in 2010 a stake in [[artisan]] bakery Flour Power City, which supplies restaurants, hotels, and caterers. Flour Power City also operates stalls in locations such as [[Borough]] Market in [[London]]. This business also became part of Patisserie Holdings.
September 2010 saw Johnson purchase Feng Sushi,<ref>Johnson, Rachel (22 September 2010).[http://www.bighospitality.co.uk/People/Luke-Johnson-buys-92-per-cent-of-Feng-Sushi "Luke Johnson buys 92 per cent of Feng Sushi"]. ''Big Hospitality''. Retrieved 28 July 2011.</ref> a London-based chain of Japanese restaurants specialising in home delivery. In the same month he also purchased a majority stake in casual-dining firm Ego Group,<ref>[http://www.bmmagazine.co.uk/Johnson-increase-portfolio-with-Ego-investment.992 "Luke Johnson increases portfolio with Ego Group investment"]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815010049/http://www.bmmagazine.co.uk/Johnson-increase-portfolio-with-Ego-investment.992 |date=15 August 2011 }}, ''Business Matters'', 14 September 2010. Retrieved 28 July 2011.</ref> which was merged in April 2011 with pizza business Rocket Restaurants to form 3Sixty Restaurants,<ref>Gibson, Heather [http://www.epmagazine.co.uk/the-full-3sixty/ "The full 3Sixty"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328071849/http://www.epmagazine.co.uk/the-full-3sixty/ |date=28 March 2012 }}, ''EP Magazine'', March 2011. Retrieved 28 July 2011.</ref> with Johnson as chairman.
In May 2011, Risk Capital Partners assumed a shareholding in Bread Ltd,<ref>Holmes, Lawrie (23 June 2011). [http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/article-2008081/Serial-entrepreneur-Luke-Johnson-roll-chain-artisan-bakeries.html "Serial entrepreneur Luke Johnson to roll out chain of artisan bakeries"]. ''This Is Money''. Retrieved 29 July 2011.</ref> a leading artisan baker. The group includes retail bakery and cafe Gail's, which has [http://www.bakeryinfo.co.uk/news/fullstory.php/aid/14691/Gail_92s_set_to_open_22nd_bakery_outlet.html twenty-two] bakeries in London and sells its products through Waitrose, Harvey Nichols and Ocado. In June 2013 he became chairman and 50% owner of Grand Union, a London bar chain.<ref>{{cite news |last=Goodman |first=Matthew |newspaper=The Sunday Times |url= http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/business/Retail_and_leisure/article1271183.ece |title=Pizza Express king heads for bar |location=London |date=9 June 2013 |accessdate=11 June 2013}}</ref>
Johnson is also the majority owner of contract catering firm Genuine Dining.
In May 2015, Risk Capital Partners announced its purchase of a majority stake in Zoggs, the global swimming products brand.<ref name=Zoggs>{{cite news |first=Dominic |last=O'Connell |title=In at the deep end |url= http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/business/Retail_and_leisure/article1551498.ece |newspaper=The Sunday Times |location= London |date=3 May 2015 |accessdate=7 May 2015}}</ref>
In 2016 he acquired a 12.5% stake in Elegant Hotels Group.<ref>{{cite web|title=MIDAS SHARE TIPS: The biggest winners and losers from 2016 - and the firms that were taken over|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/investing/article-4044050/MIDAS-SHARE-TIPS-Midas-shares-make-concrete-gains-year-twists.html|website=This is Money|accessdate=7 April 2017}}</ref> He joined the board of Elegant Hotels as a non-executive director in May 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Elegant Hotels appoints former Pizza Express chair as non-exec|url=http://www.travelweekly.co.uk/articles/279916/elegant-hotels-appoints-former-pizza-express-chair-as-non-exec|website=[[Travel Weekly]]|accessdate=26 May 2017}}</ref>
=== Patisserie Holdings === Johnson is the Executive Chairman, Chairman of the Remuneration Committee, and a 37% shareholder [http://investors.patisserieholdings.co.uk/~/media/Files/P/Patisserie-Valerie-IR/results-presentations/20171222-patisserie-holdings-annual-report.pdf] of [http://investors.patisserieholdings.co.uk/ Patisserie Holdings pl] <ref>Whitehead, Jennifer (20 September 2006).[http://www.brandrepublic.com/news/593433/C4-chairman-Johnson-buys-stake-Patisserie-Valerie/?DCMP=ILC-SEARCH "C4 chairman Johnson buys stake in Patisserie Valerie"]. ''Brand Republic''. Retrieved 28 July 2011.</ref> ([[London Stock Exchange]] EPIC code: CAKE [https://www.londonstockexchange.com/exchange/prices-and-markets/stocks/summary/company-summary/GB00BM4NV504GBGBXAMSM.html?lang=en]). The principal trading brand is [[Patisserie Valerie]]; the company's other brands include Druckers Vienna Patisserie, Philpotts, Baker & Spice, and Flour Power City Bakery. The company's auditor is [[Grant Thornton International|Grant Thornton]].
On 19 May 2014 the company was admitted to the [[Alternative Investment Market]] [http://investors.patisserieholdings.co.uk/~/media/Files/P/Patisserie-Valerie-IR/documents/14052014a.pdf]. The company had a market value of £446.13 million at close of business on 9th October 2018 [https://www.londonstockexchange.com/exchange/prices-and-markets/stocks/exchange-insight/company-news.html?fourWayKey=GB00BM4NV504GBGBXAMSM] [https://www.dropbox.com/s/axtaoxyb4wd83dk/Market%20cap%20Oct%202018.jpg?dl=0], the closing price being quoted as 425.9 pence [https://www.londonstockexchange.com/exchange/news/market-news/market-news-detail/other/13822977.html]. That evening [[Sky News]] published a news item headed: 'Patisserie Valerie owner faces crisis 'over £20m accounting hole' [https://news.sky.com/story/patisserie-valerie-owner-faces-crisis-over-20m-accounting-hole-11522365].
==== Fraud investigation at Patisserie Holdings ==== On 10th October the company's shares were suspended from trading. An announcement included information that the board had been notified of significant and potentially fraudulent accounting irregularities, that a potential material mis-statement of the company's accounts had significantly impacted the company's cash position, and that Chris Marsh, the Chief Financial Officer, had been suspended from his role [https://www.londonstockexchange.com/exchange/news/market-news/market-news-detail/CAKE/13822979.html].
On 11 October the company announced that there was a material shortfall between the reported financial status and the current financial status of the business and that without an immediate injection of capital the directors were of the view that there would be no scope for the business to continue trading in its current form. This announcement also stated that the directors and the company's professional advisers were assessing all options available to the business to keep it trading.[https://www.londonstockexchange.com/exchange/news/market-news/market-news-detail/CAKE/13825482.html].
On 12 October Hertfordshire police issued a statement saying that 'A 44-year old man from St Albans has been arrested on suspicion of fraud by false representation. He has been released under investigation.' It was widely reported that the individual concerned was Marsh [https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/oct/12/finance-director-of-crisis-hit-patisserie-valerie-arrested-chris-marsh], [https://news.sky.com/story/crisis-hit-patisserie-valerie-finance-chief-arrested-by-police-11524081]. The [[Serious Fraud Office (United Kingdom)|Serious Fraud Office]] announced on its website that it had opened an investigation into an individual at the company [https://www.sfo.gov.uk/2018/10/12/patisserie-holdings-plc/]. Later that day the company announced details of a rescue plan under which it would borrow £20 million from Johnson [https://www.londonstockexchange.com/exchange/news/market-news/market-news-detail/CAKE/13827568.html] and place 31,451,100 ordinary shares at 50 pence to raise new capital of approximately £15.7m before payment of expenses [https://www.londonstockexchange.com/exchange/news/market-news/market-news-detail/CAKE/13827697.html]. Johnson faced the choice of letting the company fail (at which point he would still have been worth over £100m), or lending money to it, albeit on terms that the majority of the loans would be repaid by the proceeds of the placings. The rescue plan prevented the imminent bankruptcy of the company and subsequent loss of 2500 jobs, but was criticised in The Telegraph as being against the interests of smaller shareholders.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2018/10/13/30m-rescue-deal-ignored-patisserie-valerie-bosses/]
On 14 October it was reported that two unauthorised and unreported overdrafts of almost £10m had been discovered.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/patisserie-valeries-secret-overdrafts-xdn0l7dl6|title=Patisserie Valerie’s secret overdrafts|last=Shah|first=Oliver|date=2018-10-14|work=The Sunday Times|access-date=2018-10-14|language=en|issn=0956-1382}}</ref>
==== Directors' share dealings ==== Johnson was the only director of the company never to have sold shares after flotation {{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}. Earlier in 2018 Paul May, the company's CEO, and Marsh both exercised share options at a price of 418p, allegedly making £1 million and £680,000, respectively. At the end of June Lee Ginsberg, deputy chairman and head of the audit committee, sold 40,000 shares at 469p, making almost £190,000 [https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/business/patisserie-valerie-owner-on-brink-of-collapse-sd5jwpd0k]. These figures relate to legitimate transactions pre-dating the crisis, with no suggestion that the board extracted cash from the company in such a way as to contribute to the alleged accounting fraud.
==== Criticisms ==== The events at the company have been criticised in a statement that 'If wonky accounting can go unnoticed at a plain-vanilla business like Patisserie Holdings, investors really have nowhere to feel safe.' [https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2018-10-10/a-cake-based-accounting-scandal-how-very-british]
===Other business ventures===
Since 2000, Johnson has run Risk Capital Partners Ltd, focusing on private equity deals. Risk Capital Partner's portfolio includes the directory publisher Superbrands, fashion chain East,<ref>Mesure, Susie (2 March 2006). [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/luke-johnson-goes-east-and-buys-stake-in-bohemian-chain-468314.html "Luke Johnson goes East and buys stake in bohemian chain"]. ''The Independent''. London. Retrieved 29 July 2011.</ref> and [[Greyhound Racing Association|GRA]], the UK's largest greyhound track owner.<ref>Bowers, Simon (1 March 2005).[https://www.theguardian.com/business/2005/mar/01/privateequity "C4 chairman buys greyhound tracks"]. ''The Guardian''. London. 1 March 2005. Retrieved 29 July 2011.</ref>
In May 2010, Johnson became a strategic investor in Beer & Partners,<ref>Rees-Mogg, Modwenna [http://www.freshbusinessthinking.com/business_advice.php?AID=6080&Title=The+Angel+Deal+Of+The+Decade+-+Luke+Johnson's+Investment+In+Beer+%26+Partners "The Angel Deal Of The Decade - Luke Johnson's Investment In Beer & Partners"], ''FreshBusinessThinking.com'', 25 September 2010. Retrieved 28 July 2011.</ref> the UK's largest business investment agency. He is also a director of two theatre production partnerships, Playful Productions and Fiery Dragons, as well as director of AKA UK, a marketing agency to the live entertainment industry. In October 2011, Johnson became a non-executive director of Metro Bank plc.<ref>[http://www.cityam.com/news-and-analysis/luke-johnson-joins-metro-bank-board "Luke Johnson joins Metro Bank board"], ''City A.M.''. London. 13 October 2011. Retrieved 22 October 2011.</ref> He was a non-executive director of art publisher Phaidon Press from August 2010 to October 2012.<ref>Gallagher, Victoria (20 August 2010). [http://www.thebookseller.com/news/johnson-does-not-rule-out-phaidon-stake.html "Johnson 'does not rule out' Phaidon stake"]. ''The Bookseller''. Retrieved 29 July 2011.</ref>
===Former investments===
In 1996 Johnson co-founded Integrated Dental Holdings, expanding it to become the UK's largest chain of dental surgeries, with over 500 dentists. The firm was sold in 2006 for over £100 million.<ref name="aboutluke" /> From 2004 to 2006 Johnson was director of Dollar Financial Group Inc, a US [[NASDAQ]] traded corporation with $80m [[EBITDA]].<ref name="aboutluke" /> He was involved in parcel delivery and maritime commerce through Nightfreight and American Port Services.
He served as a non-executive director of Elderstreet VCT plc for ten years. Through Risk Capital Partners, Johnson was a founder, part-owner and director of recruitment business [[InterQuest Group plc]]. Risk Capital Partners is also a former investor in advertising and design group Loewy, which was sold in 2006, and formerly a part-owner of fresh fish distributor Seafood Holdings,<ref>[http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=29517660 "Johnson Reportedly Mulls Stake Sale In Seafood"], "Bloomberg Businessweek", 19 September 2010. Retrieved 29 July 2011.</ref> sold in 2010 for £45m in total. Risk also held a stake in car park technology provider APT controls until 2014.<ref>Teather, David (16 February 2007).[https://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/feb/16/citynews.media1 "C4 chairman takes middle of the road position"]. ''The Guardian''. London. Retrievved 29 July 2011.</ref><ref>{{cite press release |title=Risk Capital Partners sells its stake in APT Controls to Swarco AG |url= http://www.riskcapitalpartners.co.uk/news/article.aspx?id=5eaa11ef-24ae-4025-b05a-a33300dacace |date=7 May 2014 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150223111546/http://www.riskcapitalpartners.co.uk/news/article.aspx?id=5eaa11ef-24ae-4025-b05a-a33300dacace |archivedate=23 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref>
Luke Johnson became Chairman and part-owner of [[Giraffe]] Restaurants in 2004. In 2013 he stepped down as Chairman, upon Giraffe's sale to Tesco for a reported £50m.<ref>{{cite news |last=Saunders |first=Andrew |title=Tesco blows £50m on in-store Giraffe |url= http://www.managementtoday.co.uk/news/1174573/Tesco-blows-50m-in-store-Giraffe/ |work=Management Today |date=13 March 2013 |accessdate=25 March 2013}}</ref>
==Business approach==
Among Johnson's business maxims are that, consciously or not, every successful company that he knows has followed kaizen, the Japanese management philosophy of constant, incremental improvements, often driven from the bottom up.<ref name="youtube.com">{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NL7LGtKBNW4&feature=youtu.be|title=Luke Johnson: 20 Entrepreneur Maxims - London Business School|date=16 September 2014|work=YouTube}}</ref>
==Politics==
Johnson has backed [[Vote Leave]] in the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016]].<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20160329040758/http://www.voteleavetakecontrol.org/250_business_leaders_back_vote_leave_as_new_poll_shows_eu_stops_entrepreneurs_creating_jobs</ref>
==Journalism and media== Johnson was Chairman of [[Channel 4]] Television Corporation from January 2004<ref>[http://www.ofcom.org.uk/media/news/2004/01/nr1_20040128 Luke Johnson appointed as Chairman of Channel 4 | Ofcom<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070212002131/http://www.ofcom.org.uk/media/news/2004/01/nr1_20040128 |date=12 February 2007 }}</ref> to January 2010, during which time he appointed a new CEO, restructured the board and saw the organisation enjoy record ratings, revenues and surplus.
He writes a weekly column on business for ''The Sunday Times''. He wrote a weekly essay for the ''[[Financial Times]]'' from 2007 to 2015. From 1998 to 2006 he wrote "The Maverick", a weekly business column for ''The [[Sunday Telegraph]]''. An anthology of "The Maverick" columns was published by Harriman House in 2007.<ref>{{cite book | first=Luke | last=Johnson | year=2007 | title=''The Maverick'' | publisher=Harriman House |url=http://books.global-investor.com/books/167314.htm | isbn=1-905641-40-0}}</ref>
Johnson serves on the advisory board of cultural and political magazine ''[[Standpoint (magazine)|Standpoint]]''.
==Other activities== Johnson is chairman of the [[Institute of Cancer Research]], assuming that role in August 2013.<ref>{{cite press release |title=Luke Johnson, leading entrepreneur, takes the helm at The Institute of Cancer Research |url= http://www.icr.ac.uk/press/press_archive/press_releases_2013/23652.shtml |publisher= Institute of Cancer Research |date=23 March 2013 |archivedate=17 January 2014 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140117014952/http://www.icr.ac.uk/press/press_archive/press_releases_2013/23652.shtml} |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
He is a former Chairman of The [[Royal Society of Arts|Royal Society for the encouragement of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce (RSA)]],<ref>[http://www.thersa.org/about-us/media/press-releases/luke-johnson-to-be-appointed-the-next-chair-of-the-rsa "Luke Johnson to be appointed the next Chair of the RSA"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110105182605/http://www.thersa.org/about-us/media/press-releases/luke-johnson-to-be-appointed-the-next-chair-of-the-rsa |date=5 January 2011 }}, ''theRSA.org'', 4 September 2008. Retrieved 29 July 2011.</ref> completing a three-year term in October 2012. He was governor of The [[University of the Arts London|University of the Arts]] between 2000 and 2006. He was also Chairman of Action on Addiction from 2011 to 2012.<ref>{{cite press release |title=We welcome our new Chairman of Trustees |url= http://www.actiononaddiction.org.uk/News---Publications/News/We-welcome-our-new-Chairman-of-Trustees.aspx |publisher=Action On Addiction |accessdate=22 April 2012}}</ref> In June 2012 Johnson was appointed Chairman of [[Startup Britain]], the national campaign to stimulate start-up growth in the UK.<ref>{{cite press release |title=Startup Britain Appoints Former Pizza Express Boss as Chairman |url= http://www.startupbritain.co/new/2012/06/07/startup-britain-appoints-former-pizza-express-boss-as-chairman/ |publisher=Start Up Britain |accessdate=25 March 2013}}</ref> Johnson is also Chairman of Career Colleges, an organisation planning 40 vocational colleges for 14- to 19-year-olds.<ref>{{cite news |last=Johnson |first=Luke |work=Financial Times |url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/3bef8404-3b0e-11e3-87fa-00144feab7de.html#axzz2jC6UYtgR |title=Donation of ideas is better than just cash |location= London |accessdate=30 October 2013}}</ref>
In October 2013 Johnson co-founded and launched the Centre for Entrepreneurs,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.centreforentrepreneurs.org|title=HOME - Centreforentrepreneurs|work=centreforentrepreneurs.org}}</ref> a non-profit think-tank aiming to address the "...under-represention of entrepreneurs in the public eye" and to "...promote entrepreneurship to government, media, the private sector (including big businesses) and the general public."<ref>{{cite web|last=Hunter|first=Daniel|title=Fresh Business Thinking|url=http://www.freshbusinessthinking.com/news.php?NID=20151&Title=Centre+for+Entrepreneurs#.UlbYxxavi1s|work=Centre for Entrepreneurs|accessdate=10 October 2013}}</ref>
With [[Stephen Lambert (media executive)|Stephen Lambert]] and Christopher Hird, Johnson co-produced ''The Flaw'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theflawmovie.com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110202150255/http://theflawmovie.com/ |archivedate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://theflawmovie.com/theproducers.html "The Flaw: Producer credits"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716235635/http://www.theflawmovie.com/theproducers.html |date=16 July 2011 }}, ''The FlawMovie''. Retrieved 29 July 2011.</ref> a 2011 documentary film detailing the events leading up to the financial crash of 2008. The film takes its title from Alan Greenspan's admission to US Congress that he had been mistaken to put so much faith in the self-correcting power of free markets.
==Personal== Johnson is married, with three children and lives in London.
==Publications== * ''Start It Up: Why Running Your Own Business is Easier Than You Think'' - {{ISBN|978-0-670-92047-1}} * ''The Maverick'' - {{ISBN|978-1-905641-40-6}} * ''Betting to Win'' - {{ISBN|0-948035-31-5}} * ''The Key to Making Money in the New Stock Market'' - {{ISBN|0-297-79296-2}} * ''How to get a Highly Paid Job in the City'' - {{ISBN|1-85091-474-5}} * ''30 Ways to Make Money in Franchising'' - {{ISBN|0-948032-48-0}} * ''30 Ways to Make Money in Property'' - {{ISBN|0-948032-43-X}}

{{Multiple issues| {{tone|date=May 2017}} {{refimprove|date=April 2018}} {{notability|date=May 2017}} }} {{Infobox television | show_name = M.A.D. | image = | genre = [[Children's television series|Children's]] [[Educational television|educational]] programme | country = [[India]] | language = [[Hindi]] | runtime = 30 minutes | num_series = 7 | num_episodes = 70 | company = [[Miditech]] | network = [[Pogo TV]] | first_aired = {{Start date|2005}} | last_aired = {{End date|2010}} }}
'''''M.A.D.''''', which stands for "Music, Art and Dance", is an [[India]]n [[Educational television|educational]] [[Children's Television Series|children's television programme]]. It was produced by [[Miditech]], and aired on [[Pogo TV]]. It began in 2005 and ran for seven seasons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiantelevision.com/television/broadcasting/tv-channels/kids/mad-7-on-pogo-from-11-october|title=M.A.D 7 on Pogo|date=October 9, 2009|accessdate=May 12, 2018}}</ref> It is a [[Do it yourself]] show.<ref name="TH">{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/radio-and-tv/Itrsquos-a-M.A.D.-world/article16885305.ece |title=It’s a M.A.D. world |publisher= [[The Hindu]] |accessdate=22 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="LM">{{cite web|url=http://www.livemint.com/Leisure/V9kLe9FbYoSbbmWrluFSNI/Art-in-a-MAD-world.html |title=Art in a M.A.D. world |publisher= [[Mint (newspaper)|Mint]] |accessdate=22 May 2017}}</ref> The main host and director of the show is Rob ([[Harun Robert]]). He shows how to make different easy and difficult but cool arts. He is also followed by some co-anchors in every season. The series came to an end in 2010. After the success of the show, Rob started a [[YouTube Channel]] "Mad Stuff with Rob" based on the show.<ref name="TNIE">{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/bengaluru/2017/apr/25/youtube-goes-mad-1597295.html |title=Youtube goes MAD |publisher= [[The New Indian Express]] |accessdate=22 May 2017}}</ref>
==Cast== Along with Rob, who is the artist and main host, some other co-anchors were introduced in different seasons to perform dance and play music.
===Season 1=== * [[Harun Robert|Rob]] - He is the main anchor who makes arts in 'Make It Easy' and two other unnamed sections. He also makes ''The Big Picture''. * Candy - She is the main female host in the first season. She tells facts and sometimes performs dance in ''In Motion''. * [[Palak Jain|Palak]] and Abhas - They both are child anchors, who learn arts from Rob in the second art section and then try them and shows them to Rob in the end of the show. They also tell facts and performs dance in 'In Motion'.
===Season 2=== * Rob * Palak and Abhas * Deepti - She is the main female anchor in season 2. She does the same as that of Candy in season 1. * Sid - He is a guitarist and the main member of the band shown in the season. He only plays music in 'In Stereo' section and sometimes tells thoughts.
===Season 3=== * Rob * Sid * Chinu - She is the main female anchor of season 3, which contains most number of episodes of all the seasons. She does all the works of Candy, Deepti, Palak and Abhas.
===Seasons 4 and 5=== * Rob * Rumana - She is the main female anchor of the last two seasons of the show. She tells facts and an extremely good dancer. Her original talent can only be seen in 'In Motion'.
==Format== The show does not have the simple format as that of other art and craft shows, as it not only let kids learn multiple arts, but also shows them cool dance, melodious music, interesting facts and let them meet some talented people. Each of the episode of every season except Season 5 is based on a theme and all of the dance, music and arts shown in that episode are related to that theme. It also helps children to learn about that theme. The themes are mainly water, space, camera and light etc. In every episode three arts are shown to make in two unnamed sections and in the section 'Make It Easy'. 'The Big Picture' and one of 'In Motion', 'In Stereo', 'In Action' (mostly 'In Motion') are also necessarily shown in every episode. Total sections are following-
*'''Make It Easy !'''- In these section, easy to make arts are learned to childrens. Some guest childrens visit in these section and learns them directly from Rob and sometimes even make that art with him. ''Note :''It ran for every season.
*'''Unnamed Art Section'''- In these section Rob shows some arts that are neither more tough nor more easy. ''Note :'' Palak and Abhas used to learn these arts from Rob and then make it themselves and show to Rob. This section was removed from the last season of the show.
*'''Unnamed Art Section (2)'''- In these section, Rob shows some extraordinary, coolest and most complicated arts. He is not accompanied by anyone in these section. ''Note :'' This section was also removed from the last season.
*'''The Big Picture'''- In this section, Rob along with a team makes an incredible and extreme art, which is mostly a big 3D craft made outside the set of show. ''Note :'' It ran for every season.
*'''In Motion'''- In this section, either the female anchor, or kids and other anchors perform a dance based on the theme of the episode. ''Note :'' It ran for every season but not in every episode.
*'''In Stereo'''- In this section, either Sid, or the band or any guest musician plays a melodious music related to the theme of the episode. ''Note :'' It was removed from the last two seasons.
*'''In Action'''- In this section, Rob performs some different action like flying a kite in the [[International Kite Festival in Gujarat - Uttarayan|International Kite Festival- Uttarayan]] of [[Gujarat]]. ''Note :'' It is shown for very few times and in only season 2. ''Note :'' Mainly anyone of the above three sections was included in a single episode.
*'''Studio'''- In this section, a guest person is introduced, who is much talented in any activity related to the theme. Sometimes Rob also makes arts by learning it from the guest. Some of the main guests are : Himanshu Agrawal, an [[origami]] artist, [[Ashley Lobo]], an [[India]]n [[Choreography|Choreographer]]), etc.
*'''Gallery'''- In the ending of almost each episode, Rob visits the gallery where he reads letters of kids and watches there crafts. Also in each of the episode except season 1 and 2 the gallery wall appears full of drawings during the ending credits. *'''Facts'''- In first two seasons, a different section was shown for the main anchors to tell facts. However, in other seasons facts were told without any particular section. *'''Animate'''- In this section, some animations either funny or informative. ''Note :'' It was introduced in season 4 and ran for two seasons.
'''''Sections only introduced in Season 5 :''''' Season 5 was completely a different season from others as it wasn't based on any theme. *'''Draw It Now !'''- In this section Rob shows some cool drawings which can be made in five simple steps including- make a rough shape, complete the sketch, make outline using marker, erase the pencil outline, color it. *'''Challenge Rob !'''- In this section, Rumana gives Rob a challenge to make some cool art for her using only the things that she has provided. *'''Small Picture'''- Similar to that of 'The Big Picture', a small picture is made in this section. Some of the examples of small picture are buildings made up of staple pins and an island made from vegetables.

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Judith Leyster Merry Trio.jpg | title=''The Merry Trio'' | artist=[[Judith Leyster]] | year=1629 | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric=88 | width_metric=73.5 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=London & Maastricht | museum=Collection Noortman }}
'''''The Merry Trio''''' is an oil painting by [[Judith Leyster]] in the Collection Noortman.<ref name=Hofrichter>Judith Leyster: A Woman Painter in Holland's Golden Age, by Frima Fox Hofrichter, Doornspijk, 1989, Davaco Publishers, {{ISBN|90-70288-62-1}}, catalog #9</ref> It was considered a work by [[Frans Hals]] until 1903.
==Provenance== The painting was together with Leyster's ''[[The Last Drop by Leyster|The Last Drop]]'' in the collection of the British dealer/auction house Sir George Donaldson (1845-1925) where it was documented in 1903.<ref name=Hofrichter/> The two may be pendants, as they were then reported to have the same measurements.
According to Hofrichter, the scene shows the popular ''Merry company'' theme common in 17th-century ''commedia dell'arte'' plays.<ref name=Hofrichter/> This daylight scene serves as a contrast to its candlelit pendant which warns of the dangers of drinking and smoking. Clearly, Leyster preferred the sober yet festive daytime scene, because she selected the musician on the right to illustrate her [[Self-portrait by Judith Leyster|self-portrait]].
<gallery mode=packed widths="250" heights="250"> File:Judith Leyster Merry Trio.jpg File:Judith Leyster, Dutch (active Haarlem and Amsterdam) - The Last Drop (The Gay Cavalier) - Google Art Project.jpg </gallery>

:''Not to be confused with [[Miriam Shapira-Luria]], a Talmud scholar in the Late Middle Ages'' {{Infobox artist | name = Miriam Schapiro | image = Womanhouse exhibition catalog cover.jpg | alt = | caption = By Sheila Levrant de Bretteville - Sheila Levrant de Bretteville (the photographer/designer) | birth_name = | birth_date = November 15, 1923 | birth_place = [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], Canada | death_date = {{Death date and age|2015|6|20|1923|11|15}} | death_place = [[Hampton Bays, New York]], United States | nationality = American | spouse = [[Paul Brach]] | field = Painting, Printmaking, Collage, Femmage, | training = BA, University of Iowa (1945), MA, University of Iowa (1946), MFA, University of Iowa (1949) | movement = Abstract Expressionism, Feminist art, Pattern and Decoration | works = | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = College Art Association Distinguished Artist Award for Lifetime Achievement (2002) | elected = | website = }}
'''Miriam Schapiro''' (also known as Mimi) (November 15, 1923 – June 20, 2015) was a [[Canadians|Canadian]]-born artist based in the [[United States]]. She was a painter, sculptor, printmaker, and a pioneer of [[feminist art]]. She was also considered a leader of the [[Pattern and Decoration]] art movement.<ref name="cotternyt">{{Citation | last = Cotter | first = Holland | title = Scaling a Minimalist Wall With Bright, Shiny Colors | newspaper = New York Times | date = 2008-01-15 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/15/arts/design/15patt.html | accessdate = 2009-09-12 }} </ref> Schapiro's artwork blurs the line between fine art and craft. She incorporated craft elements into her paintings due to their association with women and femininity. Schapiro’s work touches on the issue of feminism and art: especially in the aspect of feminism in relation to abstract art. Schapiro honed in her domesticated craft work and was able to create work that stood amongst the rest of the high art. These works represent Schapiro’s identity as an artist working in the center of contemporary abstraction and simultaneously as a feminist being challenged to represent women’s "consciousness" through imagery.<ref name=":1" /> She often used icons that are associated with women, such as hearts, floral decorations, geometric patterns, and the color pink. In the 1970s she made the hand fan, a typically small woman's object, heroic by painting it six feet by twelve feet.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Stein|first1=Linda|title=Miriam Schapiro: Woman-Warrior with Lace|journal=Fiberarts|date=1998|issue=24|pages=35–40|ref=Art Full Text (H.W. Wilson).}}</ref> "The fan-shaped canvas, a powerful icon, gave Schapiro the opportunity to experiment... Out of this emerged a surface of textured coloristic complexity and opulence that formed the basis of her new personal style. The kimonos, fans, houses, and hearts were the form into which she repeatedly poured her feelings and desires, her anxieties, and hopes".<ref name=":1" /> Miriam Schapiro's estate is exclusively represented by the Eric Firestone Gallery in New York.
==Early life and education== Schapiro was born in [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada.<ref name=Bloch /> She was the only child of two Russian Jewish parents. Her Russian immigrant grandfather invented the first movable doll’s eye in the United States<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.widewalls.ch/artist/miriam-schapiro/|title=Miriam Schapiro|last=Ficpatrik|first=Milja|date=|website=Widewalls|access-date=}}</ref> and manufactured "Teddy Bears."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/schapiro-miriam|title=MIRIAM SCHAPIRO|last=Salus|first=Carol|date=2009|website=Jewish Women's Archive|access-date=}}</ref> Her father, Theodore Schapiro, was an artist and an intellectual who was studying at the Beaux-Arts Institute of Design, in New York, when Schapiro was born. He was an industrial design artist who fostered her desire to be an artist and served as her role model and mentor. Her mother, Fannie Cohen,a homemaker and a Zionist, encouraged Schapiro to take up a career in the arts. At age six, Schapiro began drawing.<ref name="Gouma-Peterson">Gouma-Peterson, Thalia. Miriam Schapiro: An Art of Becoming. American Art 11.1 (1997) : 10-45.</ref>
As a teenager, Schapiro was taught by Victor d’ Amico, her first modernist teacher at the Museum of Modern Art. In the evenings she joined WPA classes for adults to study drawing from the nude model. In 1943, Schapiro entered Hunter College in New York City, but eventually transferred to the University of Iowa. At the University of Iowa, Schapiro studied painting with Stuart Edie and James Lechay. She studied printmaking under [[Mauricio Lasansky]] and was his personal assistant, which then led her to help form the Iowa Print Group.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Miriam Schapiro: Shaping the Fragments of Art and Life|last=Gouma-Peterson|first=Thalia|publisher=Harry N. Abrams Publishers|year=1999|isbn=|location=New York|pages=92}}</ref> Lasanky taught his students to use several different printing techniques in their work and to study the masters' work in order to find solutions to technical problems.
At the [[State University of Iowa]] she met the artist [[Paul Brach]], whom she married in 1946.<ref name="Bloch">Avital H. Bloch, Lauri Umansky, ''Impossible to Hold: Women and Culture in the 1960s'', NYU Press, 2005, p319. {{ISBN|0-8147-9910-8}}</ref> After Brach and Schapiro graduated in 1949, Brach received a job in the University of Missouri as a painting instructor. Schapiro did not receive a position, and was very unhappy during their time there. By 1951 they moved to [[New York City]] and befriended many of the [[Abstract expressionism|Abstract expressionist]] artists of the [[New York School (art)|New York School]], including [[Joan Mitchell]], [[Larry Rivers]], [[Knox Martin]] and [[Michael Goldberg (painter)|Michael Goldberg]]. Schapiro and Brach lived in New York City during the 1950s and 1960s. Miriam and Paul had a son, Peter Brach, in 1955. Before and after the birth of her son Peter, Schapiro struggled with her identity and place as an artist. Miriam’s Schapiro’s successive studios, after this period of crisis, became both environments for and reflections of the changes in her life and art.<ref name=":1" />
She died on June 20, 2015 in [[Hampton Bays, New York]], aged 91.<ref>http://hyperallergic.com/216461/remembering-miriam-schapiro-1923-2015/</ref><ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/25/arts/design/miriam-schapiro-91-a-feminist-artist-who-harnessed-craft-and-pattern-dies.html?_r=0</ref>
==Career== Schapiro not only honored the craft tradition in women's art, but also paid homage to women artists of the past. In the early 1970s she made paintings and collages which included photo reproductions of past artists such as [[Mary Cassatt]]. In the mid 1980s she painted portraits of [[Frida Kahlo]] on top of her old self-portrait paintings. In the 1990s Schapiro began to include women of the Russian Avant Garde in her work. The Russian Avant Garde was an important moment in Modern Art history for Schapiro to reflect on because women were seen as equals.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Richmond|first1=Susan|title=Gainesville, Georgia|journal=Art Papers|date=2004|volume=28.4|pages=42–43|ref=Art Full Text (H.W. Wilson)}}</ref>
Between 1953 and 1957, Schapiro created a substantial body of work in which she focused on the dominant style of the period: Abstract Expressionism. Miriam created her own gestural language: "painting thinly and wiping out", in which the wiped area played a significant role as the painted area. Although these works were abstracted such as her work Beast Land and Plenty, Schapiro based them off of black and white illustrations of works by the "old masters". In December 1957, [[André Emmerich]] selected one of her paintings for the opening of his gallery.<ref name=":1" />
Early in her career, Schapiro started looking for maternal symbols to unify her own roles as a woman. Her series, ''Shrines'' was created in 1961-63 with this in mind. Beginning in 1960 Schapiro began to eliminate abstract expressionist brushwork from her paintings and began to introduce a variety of geometric forms.<ref name=":2" /> It is one of her earliest group of work that was also an autobiography. Each section of the work show an aspect of being a woman artist. They are also symbolic of her body and soul. The play between the illusion of depth and the acceptance of the surface became the main formal strategy of Miriam's work for the rest of the decade.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Miriam Schapiro Works on Paper a Thirty Year Retrospective|last=Yassin|first=Robert|publisher=Tucson Museum of Art|year=1999|isbn=|location=Tucson, Arizona|pages=7–13}}</ref> The Shrines enabled Schapiro to discover the multiple and fragmented aspects of herself.<ref name=":1" />
In 1964 Schapiro and her husband Paul both worked at the Tamarind Lithography Workshop. One of Schapiro's biggest turning points in her art career was working at the workshop and experimenting with [[Josef Albers]]' Color-Aid paper, where she began making several new shrines and created her first collages.<ref name=":0" />
In 1967, Schapiro and Brach moved to [[California]] so that both could teach in the art department at the University of California, San Diego. There Miriam met her close friend David Nalibof, a physicist who worked for General Dynamics. Nalibof formulated computer programs that could plot and alter Miriam Schapiro's drawings. This was how her first feminist work, ''Big Ox #1'' from 1968 was created. The diagonals of which represented the limbs of the "Vitruvian man," while the O depicted the center of the women, the vagina, the womb. This work is described as "a newly invented, body-based, archetypal emblem for female power and identity, realized in brilliant red-orange, silver, and 'tender shades of pink'".<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/684924?mobileUi=0&journalCode=amart|title=Miriam Schapiro (1923-2015)|last=Braude|first=Norma|date=2015|website=The University of Chicago Press|access-date=|doi=10.1086/684924|volume=29|pages=132–135}}</ref> The O is also thought to symbolize the egg, which exists as the window into the maternal structure with outstretched limbs.<ref name=":0" />
Subsequently, she was able to establish the Feminist Art Program at the [[California Institute of the Arts]], in Valencia with [[Judy Chicago]]. The program set out to address the problems in the arts from an institutional position and focused on the expansion of a female environment in Downtown, L.A. In ''[[Womanhouse]]'' women were able to turn their invested creativity in rewarding their families with supportive environments toward themselves by allowing their fantasies to take over all rooms.<ref name=":1" /> They wanted the creation of art to be less of a private, introspective adventure and more of a public process through consciousness raising sessions, personal confessions and technical training.<ref>Arnason, H.H.; Mansfield, E.C. History of Modern Art. Prentice Hall. 2010. pp604. {{ISBN|0-205-67367-8}}</ref> "('House') became the repository of female fantasy and womanly dreams". Schapiro participated in the ''[[Womanhouse]]'' exhibition in 1972. Schapiro's smaller piece within ''Womanhouse'', called "[[Dollhouse]]", was constructed using various scrap pieces to create all the furniture and accessories in the house. Each room signified a particular role a woman plays in society and depicted the conflicts between them.<ref>3. Schapiro, Miriam. The Education of Women as Artists: Project Womanhouse. Art Journal 31.3 (1972) : 268-270.</ref>
Schapiro's work from the 1970s onwards consists primarily of [[collage]]s assembled from fabrics, which she called "femmages". In the early seventies, succeeding Schapiro’s collaboration in ''Womanhouse'', she made her first fabric collages in her studio in Los Angeles, which looked much like a room in a house. From the male technological world of computers Schapiro moved into a woman’s decorated house. In this home-like studio, Schapiro monumentalized her fabric cabinet and its significance for women, in a number of large femmages, including ''A Cabinet for All Seasons''. This was her poetic version of the representation of continuous changes and repetitions in all women’s bodies and lives.<ref name=":1" /> In her definition of femmage, Schapiro wrote that the style, which simultaneously recalls quilting and Cubism, has a "woman-life context" and that it "celebrates a private or public event." As Schapiro traveled the United States giving lectures, she would ask the women she met for a souvenir. These souvenirs would be used in her collage like paintings. Schapiro also did collaborative art projects, like her series of etchings ''Anonymous was a Woman'' from 1977. She was able to produce the series with a group of nine women studio-art graduates from the University of Oregon. Each print is an impression made from an untransformed doily that was placed in soft ground on a zinc plate, then etched and printed.<ref name=":1" />
Her 1977-1978 essay ''Waste Not Want Not: An Inquiry into What Women Saved and Assembled - FEMMAGE'' (written with [[Melissa Meyer]]) describes femmage as the activities of collage, [[Assemblage (art)|assemblage]], [[découpage]] and [[photomontage]] practised by women using "traditional women's techniques - sewing, piercing, hooking, cutting, appliquéing, cooking and the like..."<ref>Kristine Stiles, Peter Selz, ''Theories and Documents of Contemporary Art: A Sourcebook of Artists' Writings'', University of California Press, 1996, pp151-4. {{ISBN|0-520-20253-8}}</ref>
After 1975, Schapiro returned to New York and with what she made after selling some paintings, she not only had a room but a studio of her own. Decoration and "collaboration," are central to her artwork and both play a significant role in her house as well as in her studio.<ref name=":1" /> The studio became Schapiro’s own room and at moments of great personal conflict, the only connection with her creative self. Her various studios throughout the span of her career have reflected the changes in both the outer and the inner realities of her life. They have expressed her changing self-conceptions in accordance with or in against society, which keeps gender roles separate.<ref name=":1" /> Schapiro's studios have also become metaphors for her creative work, as well as spaces in which she could live her life and fulfill her dreams as well.<ref name=":1" />
In the process of taking on different projects, Schapiro’s studio expanded and eventually became portable, following her as she traveled from place to place. It was during the same time of her Oregon collaborative project with the nine women that Schapiro also created her first "Collaboration Series" with women artists of the past. This series combined reproductions of the work of Mary Cassatt and Berthe Morisot with colorful and sensuous fabric borders in patterns inspired by quilts.<ref name=":1" /> In ''Mary Cassatt and Me'', Schapiro overlapped her own mental image of her mother with Cassatt's maternal ideal–her mother reading a newspaper.<ref name=":1" />
In the 1990s Schapiro began exploring her Jewish identity further in her painting. Her painting ''My History'' (1997) she used the same structure as the ''House'' project and built rooms of different memories surrounding her Jewish heritage. Her most explicit Jewish-themed statement in art was ''Four Matriarchs'', stained glass windows portraying the biblical heroines Sarah, Rebecca, Rachel, and Leah. This was a colorful piece combining identity symbology and her older domesticated art to create the true vision of what high art meant to the public. ''Mother Russia'' (1994), was a fan piece made by Schapiro that drew from her family's Russian background. She depicts the powerful women from Russia each on a row of the hand held fan with a hat and a veil. She added pieces from each artist work in her "collaborative" style to join them as revolutionary women and give hidden figures praise. Her background in both the Russian and Jewish culture have very much attributed to what Schapiro’s collection of work represents. The foundation and collective use of patterns and colors describe Miriam's work and allow us to see her culture and female voice.<ref name=":0" />
Schapiro's works are held in numerous museum collections including the [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]],<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /> [[Jewish Museum (New York)]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thejewishmuseum.org/collection/artist/miriam-schapiro-american-b-canada-1923-2015|title=Miriam Schapiro|last=|first=|date=|website=The Jewish Museum|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref> the [[National Gallery of Art]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nga.gov/collection/artist-info.5457.html#works|title=Miriam Schapiro|last=|first=|date=|website=The National Gallery of Art|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref> the [[Museum of Modern Art]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moma.org/artists/5204?locale=en|title=Miriam Schapiro|last=|first=|date=|website=Museum of Modern Art|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref> and the [[Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pafa.org/collection-artists/miriam-schapiro|title=Miriam Schapiro|last=|first=|date=|website=PAFA|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref> Her awards include the Distinguished Artist Award for Lifetime Achievement from the [[College Art Association]]<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1248/is_/ai_90251597 ''Miriam Schapiro, feminist artist and Pattern & Decoration painter, received the distinguished artist award for lifetime achievement - People - Brief Article''], ''Art in America'', August 2002.</ref> and a 1987 [[Guggenheim Fellowship]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Miriam Schapiro |url=http://www.gf.org/fellows/12977-miriam-schapiro |work=Fellows |publisher=John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation |accessdate=October 19, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130104215726/http://www.gf.org/fellows/12977-miriam-schapiro |archivedate=January 4, 2013 |df= }}</ref> Miriam Schapiro's estate is represented exclusively by Eric Firestone Gallery.<ref>http://www.ericfirestonegallery.com/</ref>
==Awards and honors== * 1982: Skowhegan Medal for Collage<ref>{{cite web|title=Mairiam Schapiro Awards Page|url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/feminist_art_base/archive/cvs/735.pdf|publisher=Mariam Schapiro|accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref> * 1983: Honorary Doctorate of Fine Arts, College of Wooster, Wooster, OH *1987: Guggenheim Fellowship for Fine Arts in US and Canada * 1988: Honors Award, The Women's Caucus for Art * 1989: Honorary Doctor of Fine Arts, California College of Arts and Crafts, Oakland, CA * 1992: Honors Award, National Association of Schools of Art and Design * 1994: Honors Award, New York State NARAL * 1994: Honorary Doctorate Degree, Minneapolis and Design, Minneapolis, MN * 1994: Honorary Doctorate Degree, Lawrence University, Appleton, WI * 2002: Lifetime Achievement Award, Women's Caucus for Art
==List of major works== *(1963) ''Shrines'' [[Grey Art Gallery]]<ref>http://www.nyu.edu/greyart/exhibits/nycool/27shapiro.html</ref> *(1968) ''Big Ox No. 1'' [[Brooklyn Museum]]<ref>[http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/view_big_ox.php Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party]. Brooklyn Museum. Retrieved on 2014-01-24.</ref> *(1972) [[Womanhouse]] *(1972) ''Dollhouse'', with Sherry Brody, [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]]<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://americanart.si.edu/artwork/dollhouse-35885|title=Dollhouse, Miriam Schapiro|last=|first=|date=|website=Smithsonian American Art Museum|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref> *(1972) ''Lady Genji's Maze''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ericfirestonegallery.com/miriam-schapiro#jp-carousel-8319|title=Lady Genji's Maze|last=|first=|date=2018|website=Eric Firestone Gallery|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref> *(1978) ''Connection''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wikiart.org/en/miriam-schapiro/connection-1978|title=Connection, Miriam Schapiro|last=|first=|date=|website=WikiArt|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref> *(1983) ''Wonderland [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]]''<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://americanart.si.edu/artwork/wonderland-35394|title=Wonderland, Miriam Schapiro|last=|first=|date=|website=Smithsonian American Art Museum|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref> *(1990) ''Conservatory (Frida and Me)''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wikiart.org/en/miriam-schapiro/all-works#!#filterName:all-paintings-chronologically,resultType:masonry|title=Conservatory, Miriam Schapiro|last=|first=|date=|website=WikiArt|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref>

Yassin, and Paul Brach. Miriam Schapiro: works on paper: a thirty year retrospective. Tucson, AZ: Tucson Museum of Art, 1999. Print. ** Gouma-Peterson, Thalia, and Miriam Schapiro.
