{{other uses|Vange (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox person | name = Vange Leonel | image = | caption = | birth_name = Maria Evangelina Leonel Gandolfo | birth_date = {{Birth date|1963|5|4|df=y}} | birth_place = [[São Paulo]], [[São Paulo (state)|São Paulo]], [[Brazil]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2014|7|14|1963|5|4|df=y}} | death_place = São Paulo, São Paulo, Brazil | resting_place = Cemitério Horto da Paz, [[Itapecerica da Serra]], São Paulo, Brazil | death_cause = [[Ovarian cancer]] | partner = Cilmara Bedaque
(1995–2014) | occupation = [[Singer-songwriter]], [[journalist]], [[novel]]ist, [[playwright]], [[crônica|chronicler]], [[activism|activist]] | years_active = 1985–2014 | module = {{Infobox musical artist|embed=yes | background = solo_singer | instrument = [[Singing|Vocals]], [[rhythm guitar]] | genre = [[Post-punk]], [[alternative rock]] | label = [[CBS Records International]], [[Sony Music|Sony Music Entertainment]], Medusa Records | associated_acts = Nau}} }} '''Maria Evangelina Leonel Gandolfo''' (4 May 1963 – 14 July 2014), known as '''Vange Leonel''', was a [[Brazil]]ian [[singer-songwriter]], rhythm guitarist, [[journalist]], [[blog]]ger, [[Crônica|chronicler]], novelist, playwright, [[beer sommelier]], and [[Feminism|feminist]] and [[LGBT]] activist. Known for her distinctive [[Soul music|soulful]], [[blues]]y vocals heavily inspired by [[Billie Holiday]] and [[Janis Joplin]], she was famous for her work with [[post-punk]] band Nau, active from 1985–89, before beginning a solo career in 1991. ==Biography== Vange Leonel was born in [[São Paulo]] in 1963; great-granddaughter of [[General officer|General]] [[Ataliba Leonel]], who fought in the [[Constitutionalist Revolution|1932 Constitutionalist Revolution]],[http://minasprogramam.com/vange-leonel/ Vange Leonel #minasprogramam] and cousin of former [[Titãs]] member [[Nando Reis]],[http://som13.com.br/nau/biografia Nau's biography by former member Zique] {{pt icon}} her first musical ventures were with the [[post-punk]] band Nau ([[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] for "[[carrack]]"), which was founded in 1985. Nau released an [[Nau (album)|eponymous album]] by [[CBS Records International|CBS]] in 1987, and also took part in the compilation ''[[Não São Paulo, Vol. 2]]'', released by [[Baratos Afins]]; however, it would disband in 1989, after plans for a second studio album fell through, and Vange followed with a solo career. Her first solo album, ''[[Vange (album)|Vange]]'', was released in 1991 by [[Sony Music|Sony Music Entertainment]], and spawned her most well-known song, "Noite Preta", which was used as the opening theme of the popular Brazilian ''[[telenovela]]'' ''[[Vamp (telenovela)|Vamp]]''.[http://www.cantorasdobrasil.com.br/cantoras/vange_leonel.htm Cantoras do Brasil - Vange Leonel] {{pt icon}} Another song off the album, "Esse Mundo", would be used as the opening theme for another ''telenovela'', ''[[Perigosas Peruas]]''. Her second solo release, the [[Extended play|EP]] ''[[Vermelho]]'', came out in 1996 by the independent label Medusa Records, founded by Vange and her [[Domestic partnership|domestic partner]], journalist Cilmara Bedaque, in the same year.[http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/fsp/1996/12/13/ilustrada/36.html ''Vange mostra "Vermelho"'']. ''[[Folha de S.Paulo]]'', 13 December 1996 {{pt icon}} Bedaque also co-authored numerous of Vange's songs since the times of Nau. ''Vermelho'' was not as well-regarded as her previous album though, and Vange abandoned the musical career to devote herself to literature.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} Vange [[Coming out|came out]] as a [[lesbian]] in 1995, and since then began to milit toward the gay cause and [[women's rights]].[http://veja.abril.com.br/250603/p_072.html ''A força do arco-íris'']. Camila Antunes, ''[[Veja (magazine)|Veja]]'', 25 June 2003 {{pt icon}} In 1999 she published her first book, ''Lésbicas'', that was followed by ''Grrrls: Garotas Iradas'' in 2001; both were compilations of articles she wrote for now-defunct [[LGBT]] magazine ''Sui Generis'' from 1997 to 2000. She also wrote for the ''[[Revista da Folha]]'', ''[[CartaCapital]]'' and [[Mix Brasil]], and alongside Cilmara Bedaque she also had a [[beer]]-related blog named "Lupulinas".[http://lupulinas.cartacapital.com.br/ Lupulinas official blog]; accessed 25 August 2017. {{pt icon}} In 2000, she wrote her first [[play (theatre)|theatre play]], ''As Sereias da Rive Gauche'', that was performed in the same year under [[Regina Galdino]]'s direction[http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/folha/ilustrada/ult90u1301.shtml ''Vange Leonel estreia peça sobre lésbicas dos anos 20''], Marcelo Rubens Paiva, ''[[Folha de S.Paulo]]'', 20 June 2000 {{pt icon}} and published as a book in 2002.[http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/folha/ilustrada/ult90u27329.shtml ''Vange Leonel lança segunda-feira o livro "As Sereias da Rive Gauche"'']. ''[[Folha de S.Paulo]]'', 13 September 2002 {{pt icon}} Her first and only novel, ''Balada para as Meninas Perdidas'', was released in 2003.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} Her fifth and last literary work was the play ''Joana Evangelista'', which came out in 2006; a modern-day reimagining of [[Joan of Arc]]'s life, it deals with the theme of [[abortion]].[http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/guia/te0704200602.shtml ''Novo texto de Vange Leonel enfoca aborto'']. ''[[Folha de S.Paulo]]'', 2006 {{pt icon}} In a 2012 interview, Vange stated that she was working on a translation to Portuguese of [[Djuna Barnes]]' 1928 novel ''[[Ladies Almanack]]''.[http://acapa.virgula.uol.com.br/revista/no-brasil-ainda-tem-muito-artista-dentro-do-armario-diz-vange-leonel/13/38/15708 ''"No Brasil ainda tem muito artista dentro do armário", diz Vange Leonel'']. Paco Llistó and Lufe Steffen, ''A Capa'', 6 February 2012 {{pt icon}} Since then, however, no further announcements regarding the translation were given, and it is unknown if she got to finish the translation prior to her death. On 6 November 2014, Vange was posthumously awarded the [[Ordem do Mérito Cultural|Order of Cultural Merit]].[http://www.cultura.gov.br/o-dia-a-dia-da-cultura/-/asset_publisher/waaE236Oves2/content/omc-2014/10883 Ministério da Cultura - OMC 2014]; accessed 25 August 2017. {{pt icon}} ==Death and legacy== In mid-June 2014, Vange was diagnosed with [[ovarian cancer]], and was admitted to the Santa Isabel Hospital in São Paulo for treatment. The cancer eventually [[Metastasis|metastasized]] to her [[gastric mucosa]], evolving to a [[Terminal illness|terminal]] stage; thus, whatever treatment proved to be unsuccessful, and Vange died, aged 51, on 14 July 2014.[http://ego.globo.com/famosos/noticia/2014/07/morre-cantora-vange-leonel-aos-51-anos.html ''Morre cantora Vange Leonel aos 51 anos''], globo.com; accessed 25 August 2017. {{pt icon}} She was [[Cremation|cremated]] and her ashes were buried the next day at the Horto da Paz Cemetery, in [[Itapecerica da Serra]].[http://ego.globo.com/famosos/noticia/2014/07/corpo-de-vange-leonel-e-velado-em-sao-paulo.html "Corpo de Vange Leonel é velado em São Paulo"], globo.com; accessed 25 August 2017. {{pt icon}} ==Personal life== Vange began a relationship with Cilmara Bedaque in 1986, and the couple registered their [[domestic partnership]] in 1995. It lasted until Vange's death in 2014.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} ==Discography== ===With Nau=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Album |- | 1987 | '''''[[Não São Paulo, Vol. 2]]''''' '''(compilation)''' *Label: [[Baratos Afins]] *Format: [[Gramophone record|Vinyl]], [[Compact disc|CD]] *Contributed with the songs "Madame Oráculo" and "Sofro" |- | 1987 | '''''[[Nau (album)|Nau]]''''' *Label: [[CBS Records International|CBS]] *Format: Vinyl |- | 2005 | '''''[[The Sexual Life of the Savages]]''''' '''(compilation)''' *Label: [[Soul Jazz Records]] *Format: CD *Contributed with the song "Madame Oráculo" |- | 2018 | '''''[[O Álbum Perdido do Nau]]''''' '''(compilation; posthumous)''' *Label: [[Deckdisc]] *Format: Digital download |} ===Solo=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Album |- | 1991 | '''''[[Vange (album)|Vange]]''''' *Label: [[Sony Music Entertainment|Sony]] *Format: Vinyl, CD |- | 1996 | '''''[[Vermelho]]''''' '''(EP)''' *Label: Medusa Records *Format: CD |} ===As a session member=== ;Mercenárias * 1986: ''[[Cadê as Armas?]]'' (additional vocals in "Santa Igreja") ==Bibliography== * ''Lésbicas'' (1999) * ''Grrrls: Garotas Iradas'' (2001) * ''As Sereias da Rive Gauche'' (2002) * ''Balada para as Meninas Perdidas'' (2003) * ''Joana Evangelista'' (2006) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://vangeleonel.blogspot.com/ Official blog] (inactive since 2011) * {{IMDb name|1344474}} {{Order of Cultural Merit}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Leonel, Vange}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:2014 deaths]] [[Category:LGBT rights revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "specialist term for a work that collates all known variants of a text" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|specialist term for a work that collates all known variants of a text}} A '''variorum''', short for ''(editio) cum notis variorum'', is a work that collates all known variants of a text. It is a work of [[textual criticism]], whereby all variations and emendations are set side by side so that a reader can track how textual decisions have been made in the preparation of a text for publication. The [[Bible]] and the works of [[William Shakespeare]] have often been the subjects of variorum editions, although the same techniques have been applied with less frequency to many other works.
==Etymology== The word ''variorum'' is Latin for 'of various [persons]' and derives from the phrase ''cum notis variorum'' ('with notes by various people') which was often used in the title-pages of Dutch books of the 17th century.
==Original meaning== An older meaning of the word refers not to the text itself but to the assortment of illustrative notes printed with it: 'an edition of a text (usually [[Latin]] or [[Greek language|Greek]]) which includes annotations by a variety of critics and commentators'. Variorum editions of this kind were a speciality of [[Netherlands|Dutch]] publishers of the 17th century, including the house of [[Elsevier]]. In these editions the text is usually taken, with little or no attempt at constructive modification, from a single widely accepted critical edition of the period; the interest lies in the notes, which often fill three-quarters of each page, and which typically embody the complete commentaries of two or three recognised specialists in the work of the author in question, together with selected passages from several other commentators. The notes will usually include textual variants, both documented and conjectural, together with examples of parallel usages and (for non-fiction texts) historical information. Usually some middle-ranking literary man was appointed as general editor; occasionally, however, a first-rate scholar would preside over the edition and include original work of his own within it, [[Nicolas Heinsius]]'s edition of [[Claudius Claudianus|Claudian]] (Elsevier, 1661) being a good example.
==Notable variorum editions== A variorum of the [[Bible]] has been produced at various times in history and of various scopes. Documenting each line of text with {{em|all}} variants in wording, from {{em|all}} known source documents, presented chronologically, helps translators of the Bible establish primacy and prevalence of various line readings.
There have also been noteworthy variorums of the works of [[William Shakespeare]], including the readings of all [[Folios and Quartos (Shakespeare)|quartos and folios]]; the textual decisions, or choices, of past editors; and a compilation of all critical notes. The first was that of [[Isaac Reed]] in 1803. Variorum editions help editors and scholars understand the historical evolution of the Shakespeare texts, as well as to decode dubious lines and decide upon most likely authorial intent.
[[Immanuel Kant]]'s ''[[Critique of Pure Reason]]'' is typically presented in variorum format, with both the 1781 and 1787 editions printed side-by-side in nearly all modern editions.
[[Charles Darwin]]'s ''[[The Origin of Species]]'' went through six editions with extensive changes. The text became a third larger, with numerous parts rewritten five times. A variorum<ref>Peckham, Morse, ed. (1959), ''The Origin of Species by Charles Darwin, A Variorum Text'', [[Philadelphia]]: [[University of Pennsylvania Press]].</ref> was published in 1959.
There is also a variorum of ''[[Leaves of Grass]]''. [[Walt Whitman]] produced either six or nine editions during his lifetime. The [[New York University Press]] produced a variorum in 1980 of these various editions.<ref>Bradley, Sculley, Harold W. Blodgett and William White, eds. (1980), ''Leaves of Grass: A Textual Variorum of the Printed Poems, 1855-1891''; 3 vol., (Series: ''The Collected Writings of Walt Whitman''); New York: New York University Press.</ref>
The [[James Strachey]] translation of [[Freud]]'s ''[[The Interpretation of Dreams]]'' in volumes four and five of ''[[The Standard Edition of The Complete Psychological Works of Sigmund Freud]]'' collates eight editions.
[[Rabindranath Tagore]]'s works have been collated to produce a voluminous digital variorum. It can be viewed on the [http://bichitra.jdvu.ac.in Bichitra] website.
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Bibliography]] [[Category:Textual criticism]] [[Category:Textual scholarship]]

A '''Wallbook''' is a large printed [[book]] that is designed also to be mounted on a wall. For example, its design may be [[concertina]] folded so it can be read like a book or hung on a wall.
==Etymology== The name was coined by [[Christopher Lloyd (world history author)]], creator of the 2010 ''The What on Earth? Wallbook'' which claims to be the first ever attempt to illustrate the entire history of everything from the [[Big Bang]] to the present day on a single [[timeline]].{{deadlink|date=August 2017}} <ref>http://www.thebookseller.com/news/127565-publisher-launches-with-versatile-wallbook--.html</ref>
==Design and contents== Reviewing the book for the ''Telegraph's'' Family Book Club, the writer Christopher Middleton encapsulates the work as a "7-foot, six-inch-long chart, which starts out some four billion years ago, with the explosion that triggered the Earth’s birth, and ends just a matter of months ago, with the election of [[Barack Obama]] and the [[Global credit crunch of 2008|global credit crunch]]" of 2008.<ref name=Telegraph/>
''The What on Earth? Wallbook'' is notable for its use of a [[logarithmic time]]scale. At the beginning of the timeline 1 cm represents the passage of 1 billion years but by the end of the timeline the same space accounts for just five years. A total of 12 changes of scale accounts for how the whole of the past can be graphically represented on a single piece of paper.
The wallbook’s 1,000 pictures and captions are arranged into 12 streams of colours which provide the [[Painted photography backdrops|backdrops]] along which the major events of [[Natural history|natural]] and [[human history]] unfold. The section, "Space, Earth, Sky, Sea, Land and Humanity" accounts for the story of [[evolution]] while [[Asia]], the [[Middle East]], [[Europe]], the [[Americas]], [[Africa]] and [[Australasia]] convey the rise and fall of human civilisations.
At the top of the timeline is a series of globes that start by showing the movement of the world’s [[continental plates]] but later chart the rise and fall of major human [[empire]]s.
==Distribution== ''The What on Earth? Wallbook'' was launched exclusively through [[The Daily Telegraph]] newspaper on Saturday 4 September 2010.<ref name=Telegraph> https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/bookclub/7979831/Family-Book-Club-The-What-on-Earth-Wallbook.html</ref>
==Nomenclature== Since the launch of the ''What on Earth? Wallbook'' the word ''wallbook'' has been defined in ''Macmillan's Open Dictionary'' as a new noun meaning: "a large printed book which can be mounted on a wall". <ref>http://www.macmillandictionary.com/open-dictionary/entries/wallbook.htm</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Book design]] [[Category:Books by type]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{about|the theatre director|the railway engineer|William Bridges Adams}}
'''William Bridges-Adams''' (1 March 1889 – 17 August 1965) was an English theatre director and designer, associated closely with the [[Royal Shakespeare Theatre|Shakespeare Memorial Theatre]], [[Stratford-upon-Avon]], from 1919 until 1934.
==Life and career==
===Early years=== William Bridges-Adams was born in [[Harrow, London|Harrow]], England, the only son of Walter Bridges Adams, tutor, and his wife, [[Mary Bridges-Adams|Mary Jane ''née'' Daltry]] (1854–1939)<ref name=DNB>Speaight, Robert, Adams, William Bridges- (1889–1965), rev. Stanley Wells, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/32068, accessed 18 November 2007]</ref> and grandson of the author and inventor [[William Bridges Adams]]. He was educated at [[Bedales School]] and [[Worcester College]], [[Oxford University|Oxford]].<ref name=Times>''The Times'', 19 August 1965, p. 12.</ref>
At Oxford, Bridges-Adams joined the [[Oxford University Dramatic Society]] and played the leading roles of Leontes in ''[[The Winter's Tale]]'' and Prospero in ''[[The Tempest]]'', but his talent for direction and design was already leading him from acting to a backstage role. He staged two operas for [[Hugh Allen (conductor)|Sir Hugh Allen]], and directed the Oxford millenary pageant.<ref name=DNB/> His design was influenced by the [[Post-Impressionists]] and by personal contacts with [[Charles Ricketts]] and [[Charles Haslewood Shannon|Charles Shannon]].<ref name=DNB/>
===Directing and designing=== After Oxford, Bridges-Adams began working in the professional theatre in 1911 under the managements of [[Laurence Sydney Brodribb Irving|Laurence Irving]], [[William Poel]], [[Harley Granville-Barker]] and [[George Alexander (actor)|George Alexander]]. During this period Bridges-Adams occasionally worked as an actor, but more usually as a director and as a designer for other directors' productions. His first London production was in 1912 (a play called ''Job'', for the Norwich Players),<ref>''The Times'', 18 November 1912, p. 10</ref> and he became producer for the [[Bristol Old Vic]] repertory seasons, 1914–1915, and the [[Liverpool Playhouse|Playhouse Theatre]], Liverpool, 1916–1917.<ref>[http://www.knowuk.co.uk/doc.do?ResultsID=115B799FA7A1&SortType=relevance&searchType=quick&ItemNumber=2 ''Who Was Who'', A & C Black.] Accessed 18 November 2007 (requires subscription)</ref> His designs for stage scenery included ''The Loving Heart'' at the [[Noël Coward Theatre|New Theatre]] in 1918 ("Quite the happiest feature of the production is Mr Bridges-Adams's scenery," said ''[[The Times]]'')<ref>''The Times'', 13 June 1918, p. 9</ref> and no fewer than nine [[Gilbert and Sullivan]] operas for the [[D'Oyly Carte Opera Company]], beginning with ''[[Iolanthe]]'' in 1915, followed by ''[[Patience (opera)|Patience]]'' (1918), ''[[The Sorcerer]], [[The Pirates of Penzance]], [[Princess Ida]], [[The Mikado]], [[The Yeomen of the Guard]]'', and ''[[The Gondoliers]]'' (second act), all in 1919,<ref>Rollins, Cyril and R. John Witts. ''The D'Oyly Carte Opera Company in Gilbert and Sullivan Operas'' (1961) London: Michael Joseph Ltd.</ref> and ''[[Ruddigore]]'' (1921).<ref>''The Times'', 24 October 1921, p. 8. ''Rollins & Witts'' incorrectly gives the year as 1927.</ref>
===Shakespeare at Stratford=== In 1919, Bridges-Adams was appointed director of the Stratford-on-Avon Festival in succession to [[Francis Robert Benson|Sir Frank Benson]]. There were doubts about the continuing viability of the festival, and Bridges-Adams realised that changes and new ideas would be necessary. He threw himself into the task with great enthusiasm.<ref name=Times/> His ambition was to win for Stratford an international status on a par with that of the [[Salzburg Festival]]. He secured the services of [[Theodore Komisarjevsky]] to direct ''[[The Merchant of Venice]]'' and ''[[Macbeth]]'', and he himself produced 29 of Shakespeare's plays between 1919 and his retirement in 1934.<ref name=Times/> Unusually for the times, he presented Shakespeare's plays without cuts in the text, thereby earning the nickname 'Mr Unabridges-Adams'.<ref name=DNB/>
The original Memorial Theatre at Stratford was gutted by a disastrous fire in March 1926. Bridges-Adams' design for the stage layout of the replacement theatre (now the [[Royal Shakespeare Theatre]]) was followed by architect [[Elisabeth Scott]] when the new theatre was built in 1932.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |author2= |title= Trial flight for the Swan of Avon|url=https://www.theguardian.com/fromthearchive/story/0,,1740490,00.html |work= |publisher= [[The Guardian|Guardian]]|date=27 March 1932 |accessdate=22 August 2007 }}</ref>
In 1934 he resigned as director of the festival. ''The Times'', in its obituary notice states, possibly tactfully, that he felt new blood was needed, but the ''[[Dictionary of National Biography]]'' states that he was frustrated by the governors' failure to back him in his attempts to gain an international status for the theatre with more guest directors of international repute.<ref name=DNB/><ref name=Times/>
===Later years=== In 1936 Bridges-Adams directed [[Stravinsky]]'s ''[[Oedipus Rex (opera)|Oedipus Rex]]'' at [[Royal Opera House|Covent Garden]], and he was appointed to the council of the [[Royal Academy of Dramatic Art]] and to the building advisory committee for the [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]]. From 1937 to 1944 he worked as dramatic adviser to the [[British Council]], promoting foreign tours of British works by British stage companies.<ref name=Times/>
His publications include: ''The Shakespeare Country'', 1932; ''The British Theatre'', 1944; ''Looking at a Play'', 1947; ''The Lost Leader'', 1954; ''The Irresistible Theatre'', 1957; ''To Charlotte While Shaving'' (verse), 1957; and, posthumously, a collection of his letters edited by Robert Speaight, 1971.<ref name=DNB/>
William Bridges-Adams died at his home in [[Bantry]], Ireland, aged 76, and was buried in the Abbey cemetery at Bantry.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *Sally Beauman: ''The Royal Shakespeare Company: A History of Ten Decades'', Oxford University Press (1983) {{ISBN|0-19-212209-6}} *Marian Pringle: ''The Theatres of Stratford-upon-Avon 1875 – 1992: An Architectural History'', Stratford upon Avon Society (1994) {{ISBN|0-9514178-1-9}}
{{Authority control}}
